content: chore: adaptations for nightly-2025-05-20 #25076 Please review this PR. At the end of the month this diff will land in 'master'.
Looks fine to me. I accidentally removed @[simp] from List.ofFin_succ, but have put it back, so all these changes will disappear again.

When this sort of thing happens would you consider not making a nightly testing branch on the basis that you have to make a bunch of changes today and then unchange them tomorrow? Or does the importance of having a nightly testing branch every day trump this? I only ask because I just merged your mathlib PR which basically said "I just added ten List.ofFin_succs to simp calls but don't worry, tomorrow I'll remove them all again" and I'm thinking "why not just skip today?"

It's important that the changes happen on nightly-testing itself, because while that isn't green the Lean/Mathlib integrated testing gets harder and harder to pull off.

But there's no need to make the bump/nightly-YYYY-MM-DD branches / PRs, i.e. as appear in this message --- the Lean developers are not directly affected by the speed with which these go through.

Note that the PR, and this message, are now created by a bot --- this part is a huge timesaver.

But I think it is reasonable, and effective, for a reviewer encountering a PR like todays to just say: "let's close this one and wait for tomorrow".

(That said, I would like to keep the default that we merge these every day whenever it is reasonable to do so. Past experience has taught us that it is less work to keep up, than to have to deal with bigger batches --- where there are multiple explanations for whatever changes are happening.)
Thanks for the explanation! My point was just that had we waited in this case there would have been fewer changes, not more.
